video_title: Nils Pihl - DePIN: The Decentralized Nervous System of Physical AI - SuperAI Singapore 2025
description:
Learn more about SuperAI: superai.com
Follow us on X: x.com/superai_conf

Keynote: DePIN: The Decentralized Nervous System of Physical AI

Speaker:
Nils Pihl, CEO @ Auki Labs

Stage: io.net Main Stage
#superai #aukilabs #decentralization #physicalai #robotics 

Recorded on 19 June 2025

transcript.aggregated_text: all right there's a a lot more people than I anticipated Uh a little nervous Any friendly faces in the audience anyone I know oh yeah Terry is here Hey Terry How you doing thanks for the the uh the support Uh I'm Niels I'm with AI We work on making the physical world accessible to AI And we're doing that because we believe that things are about to get weird Over the next 10 to 20 years I believe quite strongly that civilization will grow to over 100 billion productive economic participants Most of them will be AI And as a result of this huge growth I believe that we're going to see the world economy grow by maybe as much as 10x in the next 20 years In fact I think that might be a little bit conservative For those of you that don't know over the last 20 years over the last 20 years the world economy already grew by 3x Uh I was born almost 40 years ago and the world economy has grown 10x since I was born So you only really have to believe that AI will help us move about three times as fast for us to 10x over the next 10 to 20 years Uh I think we're going to hit that pretty quickly But of course you see on the graph that something happened in the early 2000s And what happened was that software ate the white collar world Uh almost all white collar work now is done in front of a computer It's done with phones Uh desktops laptops mobile phones have been uh hugely transformative for all kinds of white collar work But 70% of the world economy is still tied to physical space and physical labor Meaning that the AI revolution can't really kick into gear until we teach machines to perceive the world So what happens next the robots are coming The glasses are coming In fact these glasses weighing only 40 g capable of spatial awareness made by a company called Menra.glglass are launching in September this year About 10 years ago Naval Ravikant wrote a blog post about what he thought would happen in the near future with AI and robots 10 years ago And in this blog post he argued that machines and AI are going to need to be able to coordinate with each other in the physical world exchange information with each other in the physical world and even buy data and resources from each other One example that he used was that self-driving cars would need to be able to negotiate with each other how to handle things like lane merges And he believed that nano transactions would help facilitate this I'm willing to pay a scent to go before you in traffic etc And at the time I lived in Beijing So this really resonated with me because Beijing is a pretty big city In fact Beijing is so big that there are more cars on the road in Beijing than there are people in Los Angeles And the average commute in Beijing is a cool 2 hours by car So if you do a quick back of the napkin calculation you will find that roughly the time it took to build the pyramids are lost in Beijing traffic every single week When we teach machines to coordinate with each other there's enormous potential that can be unlocked to make the world run faster Have you ever noticed that at a red light when it switches to green not every car starts moving at the same time there's this little chain reaction And because of that if you're far enough back you'll miss the green light But in a world where the cars are coordinating with each other and they can all start at the same time traffic will flow more uh smoothly What Naval missed in this very influential essay is that it's not enough for the cars to be able to exchange value with each other They need to be able to communicate with each other about the physical world They need to be able to express where they are physically with great precision and with low latency Because if you're a car moving at 100 km an hour you move pretty far in 10 milliseconds and the GPS is only accurate to a couple of meters So one of the things that Naval missed is that we're going to need something to replace the GPS Let me explain why by sharing some more Asia scale stories By a quick show of hands who's visiting from outside of Asia nice Okay Uh these next few minutes are for you Strap in So New York is the biggest city in the West by a pretty wide margin New York has over 900 buildings taller than 100 m A problem with that is that GPS is actually a line of sight technology Meaning when you're in an urban canyon when you don't see the sky clearly the GPS gets very imprecise Heightwise the GPS even when it is precise is 20 to 50 m off So your GPS now has no idea that you're sitting in that chair Doesn't know you're on this floor In fact GPS doesn't work indoors full stop So if you live in New York you will have noticed that the GPS can be a little bit challenging to use to navigate But I live in Hong Kong New York has 900 buildings taller than 100 m Biggest city in the West Hong Kong has over 4,000 buildings taller than 100 m And Hong Kong is just the bottom right of this picture This is the greater Bay Area home to 87 million people in an area smaller than greater Los Angeles About 2/3 the size of Greater Los Angeles And in this picture here are more high-rise buildings than all of North America and all of Europe combined in this photo right here or this illustration right here So in China in Hong Kong we are really struggling with the GPS And it turns out that robots have almost no use for the GPS at all Terry doesn't even have a GPS It's not going to help him very much So the question is what comes after the GPS machines need to learn how to perceive the physical world and communicate about the physical world They need spatial semantic perception Spatial semantic meaning spatial that they understand how far away things are the depth of things And semantic meaning they understand the thingness of things This is a bicycle Don't hit that Robots need this Your AR glasses need this Cars need this And to kind of understand what's missing for the AI revolution to really kick off I want to talk a little bit about humanoid robots I believe that the final software stack of humanoid robots needs six layers of software You need models for locomotion the ability to walk around Today robots can't even walk stairs Uh that's why Terry didn't join me on stage today He can't walk up the stairs But locomotion is most of what we've seen humanoid robots do They can walk They don't fall over Does that mean we can put them to work no We also need models for manipulation The ability to grab things pour things push things move them around And very little work has been done in manipulation so far But if you had a robot that could do locomotion and manipulation could you now ask it to go water all the plants in your home still no You need a spatial semantic perception layer so that your robot can understand the difference between watering your plant and watering your cat And you don't want the robot to just be bouncing around your apartment looking for plants It needs to have a map of your apartment and know where the plants are And it needs to be able to communicate with other robots that you have and other devices that you have if these things have moved around And it also needs to understand where it is in relation to the map It needs a positioning layer And finally you need an applications layer to tie all of these things together When these six things are in place that's when we'll see humanoid robots really start doing work At AI we focus on number three four five and six We focus on collaborative perception collaborative mapping collaborative positioning and applications that allow for a multi-root multi-device orchestration And we realized back already in 2019 to 2021 that the phones that you have in your pocket are spatial computers just like robots are In fact they're kind of robots but they don't have arms and legs So we don't even have to worry about locomotion and manipulation We can start building early on the perception mapping positioning and applications layer Two weeks ago AI closed its first multi-million dollar account with one of Europe's largest retailers where we used this legless armless robots your phones to help the retailer capture the reality on the ground to know where are their products actually not according to some plan but where did you actually place them so that they can get heat maps for the first time of how things really are performing We allow them to make easy digital twins that they can maintain just using their daily tasks And once you have that they can use AR navigation both for their staff and for the shoppers For the staff we've reduced the walking distance for click and collect orders by as much as 40% And this is possible because we have taught multiple devices multiple phones to collaboratively create an understanding of the space Early in the process it looks something like this This was stitched together from 100 separate video data streams 100 separate video data streams stitched this together And when that is in place you can use your phone to create these heat maps to do AR navigation etc But also very soon we're releasing this together with Mantra These glasses plug to a battery pack that allow the glasses to stream video for over 9 hours And that gives us something cool We can skip the locomotion cuz I'll be doing that right we can skip the manipulation cuz I'll be doing that But we will get AI perception The AI will be able to look through your eyes through this camera for a whole shift It will be able to update the map and keep track of where things are and collaboratively position all the assets resources So you get this full stack minus the locomation uh locomotion and manipulation We jokingly call it hybrid robotics There's a lot you can do with AI if you let the humans do the manipulation and the locomotion We believe that the most important thing that we can do right now at the dawn of AI is that we must make the physical world accessible to artificial intelligence This means that we have to deal with things like visual positioning allowing the camera to understand where it is in space The problem with that is visual positioning systems are a deal with the devil because what they do is they take what you're looking at and they compare it to a model of the world to find out where you are Which means you're quite literally telling the visual positioning system what it is you are looking at at all times Last year Elon Musk went on the Lex Freedman podcast and said that his humanoid robot is going to be the greatest source of data in the world Not the biggest consumer of data in the world the biggest source of data in the world Elon will know what your robot is looking at at all times The makers of AR glasses like Niantic they will know what you're looking at at all times unless we decentralize the visual positioning stack which is what AI is working on We believe that the internet itself needs a new universal spatial computing protocol that will allow venues to self-host their visual positioning system without sharing any of the data with us or anyone else The idea is if you walk into this conference center for example the conference center already knows you're here you're on the CCTV cameras but there's no reason for me or Mark Zuckerberg or Elon to know that you're here We can reduce the privacy impact of visual positioning by decentralizing the stack Instead of making one big map of the world like Niantic and Google and Tesla are trying to do we allow each venue to make its own map its own hyperlocal reality And we create a protocol that permissionlessly allows devices to visit and borrow that map even contribute to the map and be rewarded for it Sensing and mapping as a service This is called decentralized physical infrastructure networks The idea that the physical infrastructure necessary for this kind of spatial computing is not placed in one big cloud somewhere It's hosted with the different venues that you visit You can see it live at our booth just outside We're demoing a lot of cool things today And we believe that Deepin will essentially become the decentralized nervous system of AI It's how AI will be able to perceive the world know what's happening and reason with each other to kind of fulfill uh fulfill Naval's vision of robots communicating with each other Deepen allows us to deploy civilization scale infrastructure that is funded owned and operated by the people themselves We believe that deepin is a software upgrade for capitalism itself that allows us to get rid of the pernicious surveillance capitalism that gave us the moral depravity honestly of the surveillance that comes with Instagram and Tik Tok and Facebook So I only have about a minute left and I want to use the last minute to practice my Chinese homework But um come to our booth and chat with us about what happens next Will you guys humor me for a one minute pitch in Mandarin all right Um so for those of you that didn't understand me before uh [Music] Python [Music] Uh I'm Nils I am the CEO of AI Labs We are just outside We are demoing collaborative perception collaborative mapping the whole works You can try it on your phones just outside Please come to our booth and chat with us about what happens next Thank you

five and six We focus on collaborative

collaborative positioning and

multi-device orchestration
And we realized back already in 2019 to

like robots are In fact they're kind of
robots but they don't have arms and legs
So we don't even have to worry about

positioning and applications layer
Two weeks ago AI closed its first

to help the retailer capture the reality

orders by as much as 40%
And this is possible because we have

to collaboratively create an

we're releasing this together with

something cool We can skip the

we can skip the manipulation cuz I'll be

But we will get AI perception
The AI will be able to look through your

resources
So you get this full stack

manipulation and the locomotion
We believe that the most important thing
that we can do right now at the dawn of
AI is that we must make the physical
world accessible to artificial
intelligence
This means that we have to deal with
things like visual positioning allowing
the camera to understand where it is in
space The problem with that is visual
positioning systems
are a deal with the devil because what
they do is they take what you're looking
at and they compare it to a model of the
world to find out where you are Which
means you're quite literally telling the
visual positioning system what it is you
are looking at at all times
Last year Elon Musk went on the Lex
Freedman podcast and said that his
humanoid robot is going to be the
greatest source of data in the world Not
the biggest consumer of data in the
world the biggest source of data in the
world
Elon will know what your robot is
looking at at all times The makers of AR
glasses like Niantic they will know what
you're looking at at all times unless we
decentralize the visual positioning
stack which is what AI is working on
We believe that the internet itself
needs a new universal spatial computing
protocol that will allow venues to
self-host their visual positioning
system without sharing any of the data
with us or anyone else The idea is if
you walk into this conference center for
example the conference center already
knows you're here you're on the CCTV
cameras but there's no reason for me or
Mark Zuckerberg or Elon to know that
you're here We can reduce the privacy
impact of visual positioning by
decentralizing the stack Instead of
making one big map of the world like
Niantic and Google and Tesla are trying
to do we allow each venue to make its
own map its own hyperlocal reality And
we create a protocol that
permissionlessly allows devices to visit
and borrow that map even contribute to
the map and be rewarded for it Sensing
and mapping as a service
This is called decentralized physical
infrastructure networks The idea that
the physical infrastructure necessary
for this kind of spatial computing is
not placed in one big cloud somewhere
It's hosted with the different venues
that you visit You can see it live at
our booth just outside We're demoing a

that Deepin will essentially become the
decentralized nervous system of AI It's
how AI will be able to perceive the
world know what's happening and reason
with each other to kind of fulfill uh
fulfill Naval's vision of robots
communicating with each other
Deepen allows us to deploy civilization
scale infrastructure that is funded
owned and operated by the people
themselves We believe that deepin is a

that allows us to get rid of the

gave us the
moral depravity honestly of the
